Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Proprioception by fish pectoral fins: Is fin sensation tuned to fin mechanics and pattern movement?
Award.AbstractNarration: In animals, normal limb movements such as walking or reaching require sensory information from the limb regarding their movements and mechanics. While fishes use their limbs (or paired fins) for a diverse array of behaviors, little is known about the role sensory abilities plays in those functions. This project examines the fundamental question of how the sensory and motor elements of the fin propulsive system co-adapt to generate a functional neuromechanical system. In particular, it will determine how physical properties of the fins such as stiffness, size and shape, are reflected in the biological instrumentation of the fins for sensation. In addition to providing a new tractable model for studying integration of sensation and movement, data from this project will inform the design of fin-inspired propulsive devices for underwater vehicles. The broader impacts of this project will provide outreach experiences for children on the South Side of Chicago as well as opportunities for undergraduate and graduate training in the laboratory and builds educational activities at the Field Museum of Natural History.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Proprioception by fish pectoral fins: Is fin sensation tuned to fin mechanics and pattern movement? 

This grant looked for answers to the questions: How do fishes swim through the water with their fins? Are the fins sensory structures? If so, how do fin shape and bending mechanics relate to fin sensation? Our research team examined 8 species of coral reef fishes (the wrasses) that swim with their pectoral fins (the fins on the side), to explore the sensory function and mechanical design of fins that are used for endurance and maneuverable swimming. Wrasses vary in whether they flap their fins up and down in an underwater flight behavior, or move them fore and aft in a rowing stroke. We predicted that sensory neurobiology and biomechanical properties of the fins would be related, and that we would increase our understanding of animal behavior and function with this project. This research contributes to our understanding of biomechanics (how animals work), neurobiology (the function of the nervous system), and evolution (how these systems came to be).

The results of this research are that we discovered that the pectoral fins of coral reef fishes are sophisticated sensory structures in addition to being excellent propulsors. The fins are very good at sensing bending motions. The sensitivity of the fin can be measured by how strong an electrical signal the sensory nerves produce when the fin is bent. Sensitivity was quite variable along an individual fin ray, and also differed between species that flap the fins vs those that row with the fins. Using biomechanical tests from engineering, we also discovered that some fins (the flappers) are much stiffer than the fins of rowers, requiring more force to bend. A central result of this work is that the sensitivity of the fin's nervous system is tuned to the mechanical properties of the fin. There is a strong association between stiffer fins and higher sensory sensitivity to bending in flappers, with lower sensitivity and a more flexible (lower stiffness) fin in rowers.

The evolutionary results of this research are also intriguing. We used a large phylogeny (a branching diagram showing the family tree of fish species), to interpret the history of fin shape in these fishes. The pectoral fin can be treated as a wing, with a measurement of aspect ratio (length vs width) informative about its function. Higher aspect ratio fins (length 3-4 times width) tend to be stiff fins used for flapping, whereas low aspect ratio fins (length 1-2 time width) are typical of rowers. By visualizing aspect ratio on the phylogeny, we discovered that stiff, high aspect ratio fins have evolved independently at least 22 times in this one fish family. This is a fascinating level of convergence in these animals, and we predict that the sensory system has coevolved with this pattern.

Additional outcomes of this research are the development of new high-speed video and analytical methods for three-dimensional kinematics of animal movement, and a way of surgically modifying the sensory system to further explore its function. This research project involved graduate and undergraduate students in two laboratories, and produced over a dozen scientific publications and conference presentations as well as new software for broader use. This research also has potential practical applications in robotics and vehicle propulsor design.
